title: Antonio Conte is getting plenty of credit but deserves MORE - as Victor Moses and Marcos Alonso show
text:
Antonio Conte dismisses Willian to Manchester United links Share this video Watch Next 
Considering their dismal campaign last season – they are currently 30 points better off than they were at the equivalent stage of 2015-16 – it is bound to look as though players have improved. 
But it is hard to remember Gary Cahill, who also played in that 2011 Wigan-Bolton game, by the way, performing with such authority for a long time. 
Even Thibaut Courtois appears to have benefited from his latest manager’s input. Eden Hazard, meanwhile, has responded to Conte’s carrot rather than Jose Mourinho’s stick. 
If he performs, Hazard can have the freedom of the park without fear of reprisal. 
It was a telling insight last week when Conte was talking about players being uneasy watching video re-runs of matches. Marcos Alonso after scoring for Bolton in 2011 (Photo: Michael Regan) He has been key for the Blues this term (Photo: REUTERS) 
The implication was that they feared the coach would simply point out mistakes. 
It took Conte a while to convince them constructive advice was the only thing he was looking to impart. 
When you are cruising at the top of a league, there is bound to be a ­feel-good factor at the training ground, but talk to any of the staff behind the scenes and only ­positive feedback is garnered. 
Conte’s general handling of Diego Costa has gone down well, the squad has bought into a stricter fitness regime and the extra tactical analysis has grown on them. 
For his part, Conte is relishing the challenge of the Premier League and life in London and England. Which does make you wonder if Conte will finally be THE one to grow old with the owner. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
